Equivalents: ASIA 388
This course is cross-listed with ASIA 388. Students can register in either section.
This course will examine selected topics from Indian philosophy from the early period of the Upanicads (c. 7th-5th centuries BCE) up to around the eighth century CE. Our focus will be on ideas about the nature of the self and liberation or awakening. From the Brahmanical (Hindu) tradition, we will examine the philosophical ideas of the Upanicads, the philosophy of the Yoga school, the Bhagavad-g+t, and select ideas from the Nyya school. From the Buddhist tradition, we will examine the philosophical thought of the Buddha, Theravda Buddhist analyses of the person, and Mahayana Buddhist philosophy (the Madhyamaka or Middle Way school as presented by the philosophers Ngrjuna and Zntideva, and the Yogcra or Yoga Practice school as presented by the philosopher Vasubandhu).
